title-group.article-title: Annotated check list of the Pyraloidea (Lepidoptera) of America North of Mexico

2MAS, Systematic Entomology Laboratory, USDA, National Museum of Natural History, P.O. Box 37012, MRC 168, Washington, DC USA 20013-7012

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.p: An annotated check list of Pyraloidea of North America north of Mexico is presented, including 861 Crambidae and 681 Pyralidae with 1542 total species. It includes all new species described, tropical species with new records in the United States, and species introduced from Europe and Asia since 1983. The Notes section provides the seminal citations, data and/or commentary to all changes since 1983 for easy and future reference. In addition, this list proposes seven new generic combinations, the transfer of a phycitine species, Salebria nigricans (Hulst), to Epipaschiinae and its syn. n. with Pococera fuscolotella (Ragonot), and three new records for the United States. Purposefully, no new taxa are described here, but we found a gradual increase of 10% in the number of species described since 1983. Finally, we also include a list of thirteen species not included or removed from the MONA list. Many higher-level changes have occurred since 1983 and the classification is updated to reflect research over the last 30 years, including exclusion of Thyrididae and Hyblaeidae from the superfamily and recognition of Crambidae and Pyralidae as separate families. The list includes multiple changes to subfamilies based on morphology such as the synonymization of the Dichogamini with the Glaphyriinae, but also incorporating recent molecular phylogenetic results such as the synonymization of the Evergestinae with the Glaphyriinae.

sec.title: Citation
sec.p: Scholtens BG, Solis AM (2015) Annotated check list of the Pyraloidea (Lepidoptera) of America North of Mexico. ZooKeys 535: 1â€“136. doi: 10.3897/zookeys.535.6086

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This check list is an update of the Pyraloidea by Munroe (1983) and Klots (1983) in Hodges et al. (1983) (hereafter referred to as the MONA check list) that is now over 30 years old. An updated list of Pyraloidea of North America north of Mexico is greatly needed because there have been many new species described, higher-level taxonomic and nomenclatural changes, additions and deletions, new synonymies and combinations, and new introductions to the fauna since 1983.

The additional species included in this check list are from three primary sources: newly described species (Table 1), tropical species newly reported from the United States, and new introductions from Europe and Asia (Table 2). Species listed here are mostly established, breeding populations, but also include some strays and recent introductions which may not, ultimately, become established. This check list is also highly influenced by the publication in 1995 of the first check list of Neotropical pyraloids (hereafter known as the NTCL or Neotropical check list) (Munroe 1995a,b; Solis 1995; Solis, Becker and Munroe 1995; M. Shaffer and Solis 1995; J. Shaffer 1995). This list included many changes to the MONA check list because it included species in America north of Mexico (indicated with an * in the NTCL) that were described mostly from U.S. states that border Mexico and could possibly extend south into the Neotropical region. In addition, the results of studying and comparing type specimens over many years by the authors resulted in many new combinations and synonymies that affected American pyraloid nomenclature.

caption.p: Faunal additions to list as either introductions or recorded from southern states.

tr.td: Dixon and Anderson 2014a, Hayden and Troubridge 2015

sec.p: The MONA check list was the product of a number of sequential lists of the known Pyraloidea species in the United States and Canada beginning over 100 years ago (Grote 1882, Fernald 1891 in Smith 1891, Fernald 1903 and Hulst 1903 in Dyar 1903, Barnes and McDunnough 1917, McDunnough 1939, Munroe 1983 and Klots 1983 in Hodges et al. 1983). These lists progressively added more species, with the MONA check list more than doubling the known total from 1903 (Table 3; Figure 1). The MONA check list included 807 species in the Crambidae and 567 species in the Pyralidae. To the best of our knowledge the present list is complete up to August 2015. This check list includes 861 species in the Crambidae and 681 species in the Pyralidae from North America north of Mexico, 168 more than the 1983 list and a total of 1542 species, an increase of more than 10%.

caption.p: Total number of Pyraloidea species in North America north of Mexico in major published lists.
Number of Pyraloidea species reported in major North American lists.

tr.td: Munroe & Klots in Hodges et al. 1983

sec.p: A number of workers contributed to our increased knowledge about the identity and relationships among pyraloid species in America north of Mexico after the MONA check list was published. Eugene Munroe continued to publish, along with A. Blanchard, E. C. Knudson, B. Landry, H. H. Neunzig, J. Shaffer, and M. A. Solis, most actively describing species, revising groups and adding to the North American list of pyraloids. Within the last 30 or 40 years major revisions of subfamilies that included American species or genera included the Scopariinae (Munroe 1972a), Acentropinae (Munroe 1972a as Nymphulinae; Speidel 2005), Odontiinae (Munroe 1972b), Glaphyriinae (Munroe 1972b, 1973 including Evergestinae), Pyraustinae (Munroe 1976a,b), Crambinae (Landry 1995), Schoenobiinae (Martinez 2010) (but new names not yet published), Chrysauginae (Cashatt 1968, 1969; Solis et al. 2013), Epipaschiinae (Solis 1993), and most of the Phycitinae (Neunzig 1986, 1990, 1997, 2003; Shaffer 1968).

In addition, recent work in Europe, particularly that by Maes (1987, 1994, [2002], 2003, 2005), Leraut (1997, 2002, 2003a, 2003b, 2005a, 2005b, 2006a, 2006b, [2008], 2012, 2014) and Nuss (1999, 2005), and work by contributors to the Global Information System on Pyraloidea (Nuss et al. 2003â€“2015), has clarified placement of many North American taxa and synonymized several genera with European genera.

We have made significant higher-order taxonomic and/or nomenclatural changes from the MONA check list to reflect Pyraloidea systematic research in the last 40 years. Most prominently this includes the removal of Thyrididae and Hyblaeidae from the Pyraloidea (Minet 1985), and splitting the Pyralidae (sensu lato) into two families, the Crambidae and Pyralidae (sensu stricto) (Minet 1982); Munroe (1983) used the informal terms of Series Crambiformes and Series Pyraliformes, but followed Minetâ€™s division of two families in Munroe (1995a). We also have adopted the subfamily arrangement of Regier et al. (2012) based on recent molecular evidence that supported the morphological evidence or hypothesized new relationships and/or synonymies. The Pyralidae subfamilies remain the Chrysauginae, Galleriinae, Pyralinae, Epipaschiinae, and Phycitinae as in Munroe (1983), with the exception of the Peoriinae, now considered part of the Phycitinae (Minet 1982) and relegated to tribal status within the Phycitinae by Solis and Mitter (1992). In the Crambidae, there are several major changes from the MONA check list. 1) The subfamily Evergestinae is synonymized with Glaphyriinae, as the oldest name, based on Regier et al. (2012). 2) The genera in the tribe Dichogamini (in the Odontiinae in MONA) are placed in the Glaphyriinae (Munroe and Solis 1999). 3) The genera in the tribe Ambiini (in the Nymphulinae in MONA) are placed in the Musotiminae (Speidel 1981). 4) The name Acentropinae is applied to the Nymphulinae (in MONA) as the oldest name for the group (Solis 1999; ICZN 2003). 5) The tribes Pyraustini and Spilomelini are elevated to subfamily level (Minet 1982). 6) The subfamily Cybalomiinae is deleted from the North American region, its lone species transferred to Glaphyriinae (Solis 2009). 7) The genera in the subfamily Ancylolomiinae (in MONA) are placed in the Crambinae (Landry 1995; Munroe 1995a). 8) The subfamily Lathrotelinae is recognized for the genus Sufetula (Minet 2015).

In this check list we give the complete synonymy as currently known for all species, and list known subspecies with synonyms, indicating where taxa are extralimital or introduced. We have reorganized many of the genera based on the NTCL (Munroe 1995a, b; Solis 1995; Solis, Becker and Munroe 1995; M. Shaffer and Solis 1995; J. Shaffer 1995) because it reflects a more recent concept of generic relationships. We have also followed Landry (1995) for the arrangement of genera in the Crambinae. We have not included the taxonomic rank of tribe because so many are not based on characters, or the tribal structure breaks down upon study of the tribe in other regions of the world. We also list described subgenera as synonyms because they are not universally applied to most of the list.

MAS has externally examined types or vouchers for much of the Western Hemisphere fauna, and we have confirmed vouchers for the recorded introductions. Researchers in other parts of the world have examined species, internally as well as externally, and, in some cases, synonymized some of the older generic names (e.g. Anania â€“ Leraut 2005a; TrÃ¤nker et al. 2009, Elophila â€“ Yoshiyasu 1985; Speidel 2005, Hypsopygia â€“ Leraut 2006a). In some cases when the genus was synonymized, new combinations of species were not published. We include those combinations in this list based on the synonymies indicated in those publications. Citations for all species described since the MONA check list are included in the References, but citations for older species descriptions are not included. Taxa with a superscript number, e.g. 122, have a corresponding note in the Notes section explaining or clarifying information about that name (e.g. new synonymies, recent introductions, and discoveries regarding Neotropical taxa that extend northward). Authors and years in parentheses, e.g. (Walker 1859), indicate that the species was originally described in another genus. For all names, the original genus is listed in parentheses after the complete name (even when the same as the current genus). The original spelling of the specific epithet is used to maintain consistency with recent lists by Lafontaine and Schmidt (2010) and Poole (1996). By listing the original spelling, appropriate combinations can be formed by future authors based on the gender of any current or future generic placement following ICZN article 34.2 (ICZN 1999). Brackets around the year of publication, e.g. Walker, [1866], indicate that the year of publication has been determined to be different from that in the publication. Our synonymy includes only names associated with descriptions or emendations; we have eliminated misapplied names and misspellings that have often been listed in previous check lists. In several cases, the attribution of authorship has been corrected because the author of the name was not the same as the author of the overall publication. The most prominent of these are Ragonot, E. L. & Hampson, G. F. 1901 [November 22] (Fletcher and Nye 1984) and authorship by Cramer and/or Stoll (1779â€“1782) (Fletcher and Nye 1982). Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015) also indicate that authorship of Felder (1875) should actually be Felder, C., Felder, R. & Rogenhofer, A.F. (1875) (Fletcher and Nye 1979).

We opted not to create a new numbering system for the list, but have included the original MONA and NTCL numbers (even when a name is in new synonymy) for cross-reference to those lists. We anticipate a new numbering system will be in place when the entire North American check list becomes available on-line. When lists are numbered, the computer sorting and ordering of taxa phylogenetically becomes onerous, particularly as species are reassigned to genera or subfamilies and new species are described. In our database, we have assigned sequential numbers to superfamilies, families, subfamilies, tribes and genera, in addition to species (currently with MONA numbers and additions interpolated with decimals). Figure 2 shows a data record illustrating this system. These number assignments are for internal database use only and allow for correct hierarchical sorting to higher-level taxa while still retaining the original species numbers, allowing phylogenetic sorting rather than only alphabetic. This logic could easily be extended to subgenera or species groups, particularly for very large genera. This avoids complete renumbering of species in the database, and allows easy reference to the previous list. We intend to keep this database (maintained by BGS) current, including updates in GlobIZ (Nuss et al. 2003â€“2015). The database can generate an unformatted version of this check list, or export into Excel format.

caption.p: Data record illustrating numbering system to enable phylogenetic sorting without new species numbers.

sec.p: We and our colleagues who study Pyraloidea are aware of other undescribed species, new synonymies, and new combinations, but we have not included these in the list pending publication. Molecular data have also recently been applied to species level questions in the Pyraloidea, (e.g. Anania â€“ Yang et al. 2012) and we expect additional discoveries and changes to nomenclature. Small groups such as the Pyralinae, Epipaschiinae, and Galleriinae are likely to have just a handful of additional species when revised at the species level. Most future additions are likely to be in the largest subfamilies, the Spilomelinae, Crambinae, and Phycitinae where some genera remain to be described, larger genera are known to be polyphyletic (see misplaced species at the end of genera in the NTCL), and smaller genera may be paraphyletic to other genera. Recent molecular work has largely supported previous morphological studies, but we expect generic concepts to experience significant changes in the future because most generic taxonomic groupings still require adequate investigation using morphological and molecular techniques.
We plan to continue updating this list, thus we welcome information on omissions, corrections, additions or updates.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank the many researchers who have collected, described, and reported Pyraloidea over the last 30 years. Eugene Munroe, in particular made the development of this list possible by actively tracking North American and Central American records for many decades, describing species, and revising multiple groups in the Pyraloidea. Herb Neunzig revised a large percentage of the Phycitinae of North American since the MONA list. Bernard Landry published an important analysis of the Crambinae, reassigned many species to new genera, and described several species. Tim Cashatt completed work on the Chrysauginae and Jim Hayden published on parts of the Odontiinae. Jim also provided important encouragement and has actively sought new records from Florida along with Terry Dickel. Over many years Andre Blanchard, Charles Bordelon, and Ed Knudson have discovered species occurring in Texas. MAS has had the pleasure of working with the extensive Blanchard collection primarily from Texas and with Ed Knudson and Charles Bordelon on species new to Texas and the United States. Many individuals, including James Adams, George Balogh, Vernon Brou, Cliff Ferris, Bernard Landry, Steve Passoa, Jim Vargo and many others provided valuable information on introduced species or new records for the United States. The Jack Franclemont collection of beautifully spread pyraloids at the NMNH provided and/or confirmed new species occurring in Arizona. Mark Metz and Jon â€œBuckâ€ Lewis, Systematic Entomological Laboratory, USDA, created a database, tracked down original descriptions, and photographed type specimens and their genitalia for an NMNH pyraloid type database that was crucial to this paper. James Carpenter and Dave Grimaldi (American Museum of Natural History, New York) made available photographs and/or specimens of the Hulst types needed for this study deposited at their institution. Michael Shafferâ€ and Kevin Tuck (retired)(The Natural History Museum (NHM, London) made available especially Grote, but some Zeller and Druce type specimens deposited at the NHM. The list was significantly improved by the meticulous reading and editing of James Hayden and Bernard Landry.

Speidel WMey W (1999) Catalogue of the oriental Acentropinae (Lepidoptera, Crambidae). Tijdshrift voor Entomologie 142: 125â€“142. doi: 10.1163/22119434-99900025
Sullivan JBSolis MA (2013) A new species of Palpita (Crambidae, Spilomelinae) from the coastal plains of southeastern United States. ZooKeys 264: 3â€“9. doi: 10.3897/zookeys.264.4363

Systematic Entomology 37: 687â€“705. doi: 10.1111/j.1365-3113.2012.00637.x

Zimmerman EC (1958) Lepidoptera: Pyraloidea. Insects of Hawaii, 456 pp.

fn.p: Sarabotys cupreicostalis is here reported for the first time in the United States from Arizona by MAS. Five specimens are deposited in the NMNH (National Museum of Natural History, Washington, DC): Babquivari Mts., Pima Co., 1â€“15 Sept. 1923 (2 specimens); Huachuca Mts., Aug. 16â€“23, Barnes Coll. (1 specimen); and Huachuca Mts., Miller Canyon, 5000â€™, Cochise Co., 18 July 1974, J. G. Franclemont (2 specimens).
Sclerocona acutellus was first reported in the United States from Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maryland, and Rhode Island by Wagner et al. (2003).
Leraut (2012) recognized sinensellus as a subspecies.
Pseudopyrausta marginalis was first reported in the United States from Texas by Bordelon and Knudson (2010) in the 2009 Season Summary and discussed again in Bordelon and Knudson (2011).
These names were recognized as synonyms by Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015).
Many new synonyms and several subspecies were recognized in Munroe (1995a,b). If not specifically footnoted, this is true in all cases where we do not list a MONA #, but do list an NTCL #.
An expanded concept of Anania is recognized as in Leraut (2005a) and TrÃ¤nker et al. (2009).
Mutuuraia and Nealgedonia were synonymized with Algedonia in Maes (2005).
Anania tertialis and plectilis were elevated to species status in Yang et al. (2012).
Anania tennesseensis was described in Yang et al. (2012).
Aponia aponianalis was first reported in the United States from Texas, by Bordelon (2011) in the 2010 Season Summary and discussed in Bordelon and Knudson (2011).
Dosara was synonymized with Achyra in Maes (1987).
Sitochroa palealis was first reported in the United States from Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, and Wisconsin by Passoa et al. (2008).

Paracorsia repandalis is here reported for the first time in the United States from Indiana by Jim Vargo. Specimens at the FMNH (Florida Museum of Natural History): Mishawaka, 41Â°37â€™46.2â€N -86Â°08â€™13.9â€, St. Joseph Co. on 11 Aug 2010 and again on 14 Aug 2012. Identification by James Hayden.
Leimonia was synonymized with Loxostege in Maes (1994).
Meridiophila was synonymized with Loxostege in Leraut (2005a).
Proteroeca was synonymized with Pyrausta in Maes (1994).
Mardinia was synonymized with Pyrausta in Maes (2002).
Pyrausta cardinalis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden et al. (2011).
Pyrausta insequalis replaced subsequalis as the accepted name in Munroe (1995a).
Pyrausta borealis was recognized as a distinct species in Poole and Lewis (1996).
Daulia was moved to the Pyraustinae by Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015) based on structure of the genitalia and tympanum.

Ecpyrrhorrhoe puralis was first reported in the United States from Alabama, Georgia, Kentucky, Maryland, Mississippip, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennnessee, and West Virginia by Solis et al. (2010).
Spilomelinae was recognized as a subfamily in Minet [1982], Solis and Maes (2002), and Regier et al. (2012).
Phaedropsis principialis was recognized as a new combination in Munroe (1995a).

Framinghamia was synonymized with Phlyctaenia (Maes 1994), and then subsequently with Anania (Leraut 2005a) in the Pyraustinae, but Hayden (pers. comm.) places it back in the Spilomelinae as in Munroe (1983) based on the morphology of the genitalia.
Hyperthalia was synonymized with Lygropia in VÃ¡ri, Kroon and KrÃ¼ger (2002).
Lygropia fusalis was first reported in the United States by Munroe (1995a) through synonymy of Nacoleia hampsoni.
This species is indicated as misplaced in Munroe (1983).
This species is indicated as misplaced in Munroe (1995a).
Lygropia memmialis was recognized as a species in Munroe (1995a), but its new status was not indicated.
Cyclocena was synonymized with Microthyris in Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Microthyris lelex was first reported in the United States by Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Pantographa suffusalis was first reported in the United States in Texas by Bordelon (2009) and discussed in Bordelon and Knudson (2009).
Pleuroptya penumbralis was synonymized with Pleuroptya silicalis in Munroe (1995a).
Herpetogramma ipomoealis was synonymized with Pleuroptya fluctuosalis (Lederer), which was transferred to Herpetogramma in Munroe (1995a).
Botys otreusalis was synonymized with Herpetogramma phaeopteralis in VÃ¡ri, Kroon and KrÃ¼ger (2002).
Acharana descripta was synonymized with Herpetogramma phaeopteralis in Solis (2010).
The identity of Herpetogramma centrostrigalis was confirmed in Solis (2010).
Herpetogramma sphingealis was described in Handfield and Handfield (2011).
Blepharomastix magualis, aplicalis, rehamalis, and differentialis were transferred to Hileithia in Munroe (1995a).
Hileithia decostalis was first reported in the United States from Mississippi by Mather and Munroe (1992).
Stenia pulchellalis was synonymized with Hydriris ornatalis in Viette (1990).
Ercta ornatalis orientalis was synonymized with Ercta ornatalis ornatalis in Inoue (1982).
Lineodes triangulalis was reported in the United States from Florida and Texas by Hayden and Dickel (2014), although it had been previously reported from Florida by Dyar (1901).
Lineodes elcodes was first reported in the United States from California by Epstein (2004).
Lineodes multisignalis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Covell and Hayden (2014).
Lineodes vulnifica was first reported in the United States by Annand (1945) (Hayden pers comm.).
Zellerina (replacement name for Stenoptycha) was synonymized with Atomopteryx in Munroe (1995a).
Lamprosema baracoalis was first reported in the United States from Texas by Blanchard and Knudson (1985a).
Neoleucinodes torvis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1985) and discussed in Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Udea aenigmatica was transferred from Platytes and recognized as a distinct species by Landry (1991).
Desmia divisalis was synonymized with Desmia ufeus in Munroe (1995a), but its status as a new synonym was not indicated.
Desmia propinqualis was synonymized with Desmia ploralis in Munroe (1995a).
Blepharomastix eudamidasalis was transferred to Diasemiodes in Munroe (1995a).
Hymenia exodias was synonymized with Spoladea recurvalis in Zimmerman (1958).
Nacoleia charesalis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden in Dixon and Anderson (2014a) and later discussed in Hayden and Troubridge (2015).
Duponchelia fovealis was first reported in the United States from California by Epstein (2004), and later discussed by Brambila and Stocks (2010) and Heppner and Brambila (2010).
Stemorrhages costata was transferred to Diaphania in Munroe (1995a), but its status as a new combination was not indicated; it was indicated as misplaced.
Dysallacta was synonymized with Glyphodes in Inoue (1982).

Glyphodes batesi was removed from synonymy with Glyphodes sibillalis by Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015). Comparison of the type specimen of Glyphodes batesi shows that it is a junior synonym of Glyphodes sibillalis and is included in this list.

Spelling corrected (misspelled in MONA as atlitalis); Glyphodes alitalis Hulst, 1886 (type locality USA) was synonymized with Glyphodes bivitralis GuenÃ©e, 1854 (from India) by Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015). After a comparison of a photo of the type of Glyphodes alitalis at the AMNH and the description of Glyphodes bivitralis we found that Munroe was correct in 1983 when he noted Glyphodes bivitralis as â€œauthors, part, not Guenee 1854â€ so we exclude Glyphodes bivitralis from this list.

Glyphodes onychinalis was first reported in the United States from California by Solis (2008). It had been sighted and sent to MAS by Don Sterba who collected it in Culver City (Los Angeles Co.) as early as 2007; Ron Leuschner had seen it in his backyard in Manhattan Beach as early as 2006. Leuschner (2009) reported it from Los Angeles Co., Manhattan Beach.
Maruca vitrata was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1981).
Maruca testulalis, a pest of legume crops, was first synonymized with Maruca vitrata in Munroe (1995a), although not explicitly stated as a new synonym (Solis 2003).

The names fortificalis (MÃ¶schler, 1890) and pigralis (Dognin, 1909) listed in Munroe (1995a) were found to be synonyms of Omiodes metricalis (MÃ¶schler, 1881) by Gentili and Solis (1998) and are excluded here.
Omiodes exogrammalis was synonymized with Omiodes stigmosalis in Munroe (1995a).
Omiodes martyralis was first reported in the United States from Louisiana by Brou (1985) and discussed in Brou (1994).
Sylora was synonymized with Palpita in Shaffer et al. (1996).
Palpita persimilis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden and Buss (2012).
Palpita euphaesalis was synonymized with Palpita illibalis in Munroe (1995a).
Palpita maritima was described in Sullivan and Solis (2013).
Polygrammodes oxydalis was recognized as a species distinct from Polygrammodes flavidalis in Munroe (1995a), but its new status was not indicated.
Loxomorpha and Maracayia were recognized as part of the Siga group and moved to near Laniifera by Landry, Roque-Albelo, and Hayden (2011).
Gonocausta sabinalis was omitted from Munroe (1983) but included in Munroe (1995a) from Texas.

Epipagis fenestralis was recognized as an unused senior synonym for Epipagis huronalis in Munroe (1995a) (see Note 143: 171 in Munroe (1995a) for a full explanation of the status of Epipagis fenestralis).
Nomophila triticalis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Heppner (2011) and discussed in Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Samea druchachalis was first reported in the United States from Texas by Bordelon and Knudson (2011).
Sameodes albiguttalis was transferred to Niphograpta in Munroe (1995a).
Somatania was recognized as a synonym of Crocidocnemis in Munroe (1995a).
Marasmia was synonymized with Cnaphalocrocis in Shaffer et al. (1996).
Bradina andresi was synonymized with Cnaphalocrocis trapezalis in VÃ¡ri, Kroon and KrÃ¼ger (2002).
Salbimorpha was synonymized with Salbia in Munroe (1995a).
Cangetta micralis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden and Dickel (2014).

Eurrhyparodes splendens was first reported in the United States from Texas by Blanchard and Knudson (2007), but also reported as a new state record from Arizona by Bordelon (2007) in the same 2006 Season Summary.
Hydropionea was included in Munroe (1995a) under â€œUnplaced Generaâ€; its placement needs to be investigated further (Hayden pers. comm.).
Falcimorpha (replacement name for Falx) was synonymized with Microphysetica in Munroe (1995a).
Microphysetica philogelos was synonymized with Microphysetica hermeasalis in Munroe (1995a).
Pilocrocis glaucusalis was recognized as a species of Palpusia in Munroe (1995a).
Rhectocraspeda was recognized as the new generic name for Pilemia (preoccupied) in Munroe (1995a).
Araschnopsis was synonymized with Sisyracera in Munroe (1995a).
Sisyracera contortilinealis was first identified in the United States from Florida by Hayden (pers. comm.) based on a 2012 specimen from Monroe Co.
Plumipalpiella was established as a replacement name for Plumipalpia (preoccupied) in Munroe (1995a).
Frechinia murmuralis was recognized as a species in Munroe (1995a), but was not listed as new status.
Hercyna was synonymized with Metaxmeste in Fletcher and Nye (1984).
Chlorobaptella was established as a replacement name for Chlorobapta (preoccupied) in Munroe (1995a).
Metrea was synonymized with Cliniodes by Hayden (2011) and belongs in the Odontiinae (Munroe 1995a, Hayden 2011). Dichogamini was transferred to Glaphyriinae (see Note #100 below).
Basonga was synonymized with Cliniodes in Klima (1939).
Procliniodes was described as a subgenus of Cliniodes in Hayden (2011).
Dichogamini was transferred to Glaphyriinae in Munroe and Solis (1999).
Schacontia was transferred from Cybalomiinae to Glaphyriinae in Solis (2009).
Schacontia themis was described and first reported in the United States from Florida by Goldstein et al. (2013).
Schacontia rasa was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden in Dixon and Anderson (2015).
Ashwania was synonymized with Hellula in Shaffer et al. (1996).
Aethiophysa invisalis was recognized as the senior synonym of Aethiophysa lentiflualis in Munroe (1995a).
Cybalomia extorris was transferred to Aethiophysa in Solis (2009).
Ennomosia basalis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Lipocosma albinibasalis was established as a replacement name for Lipocosma albibasalis (preoccupied) in Munroe (1995a).
Evergestinae was synonymized with Glaphyriinae in Regier et al. (2012).
Maelinoptera was synonymized with Evergestis in Nuss (2005).
Reskovitsia was synonymized with Evergestis in Maes (1994).

Evergestis palousalis was recognized as the senior synonym of Evergestis obscuralis (preoccupied) in Munroe (1995a). Evergestis palousalis obscuralias was established as the replacement name for the subspecies previously recognized as Evergestis obscuralias obscuralis.
Evergestis dischematalis was established as the replacement name for Evergestis dimorphalis (preoccupied) in Munroe (1995a).
Speidel (1981) resurrected Musotiminae Meyrick, 1890 and synonymized Ambiini Munroe, 1972 which included Undulambia.

Neomusotima conspurcatalis was recognized as established due to biocontrol introduction in the United States by Boughton and Pemberton (2012). Ambia conspurcatalis was combined with Neomusotima in Solis et al. (2004).
Musotima fuscalis was synonymized with Neomusotima conspurcatalis in Solis et al. (2004).
Sineudonia was synonymized with Scoparia in Li et al. (2010).
Dipleurina, Malageudonia, and Vietteina were synonymized with Eudonia in Nuss (1999).
Eudonia alpina was recognized as the senior synonym of Eudonia lugubralis in Nuss (1999). The Old World synonyms not previously listed are included here.
Klots (1983) omitted Old World synonyms for species in the Crambinae. These are added here as in Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015).
The order of genera in the Crambinae follows Landry (1995).
Surattha santella and Surattha indentella were transferred to Prionapteryx by Bleszynski (1967). Landry (1995) retained these two species in Surattha as in Klots in Munroe (1983) and Munroe (1995a).
Loxophantis was synonymized with Prionapteryx in Bassi (2013).
Alloea was synonymized with Prionapteryx in Shaffer et al. (1996).
Spelling corrected; incorrectly spelled as huachucella in Klots (1983) and Munroe (1995a).

Fletcher and Nye (1984) referred Acigona to the Noctuidae. Agnew (1987) addressed the nomenclatural problem dealing with various crambine genera including Occidentalia. Munroe (1995a) mentioned that Occidentalia does not belong in the Haimbachiini. Landry (1995) listed Occidentalia as a separate genus in the Haimbachiini. None of the authors above explicitly indicated its new status as a new combination.
Eoreuma arenella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1983a).
Diatraea mitteri was described in Solis et al. (2015).

All species in the United States formerly in the genus Vaxi were transferred to Argyria in Munroe (1995a). Argyria auratella and Argyria critica were not listed as new combinations, but Argyria tripsacas was. There were no changes in Landry (1995).
Argyria of the southeastern United States was reviewed by Martinez and Brown (2007).
Argyria argentana Martyn, 1797 is not the correct name for Argyria nummulalis because it is a nomen nudum according to Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015).
Pseudoancylolomia was synonymized with Euchromius and Pseudoancylolomia qadrii was synonymized with Euchromius ocellea in Schouten (1992).
This species was indicated as misplaced in Klots (1983).
Catoptria tristis was synonymized with Catoptria trichostomus in Sinev (2008).
Thaumatopsis bolterellus was transferred from Parapediasia in Landry (1995).
Thaumatopsis digramellus was first reported in the United States from Arizona by Landry (1995). Specimens were collected by O. C. Poling from Indian Oasis, Sells P.O., Pima Co. on 15â€“30 Apr 1922.
Fissicrambus albilineellus was transferred from Crambus in Landry (1995).
Fissicrambus quadrinotellus was transferred from Crambus in Bleszynski (1963, 1967), and also listed in Landry (1995).
Loxocrambus coloradellus was transferred from Crambus in Landry (1995).
Loxocrambus hospition was transferred from Fissicrambus in Landry (1993).
Neodactria was described as a new genus, and Crambus caliginosella, Crambus luteolella, Crambus modestella, Crambus murella, and Crambus zeella were all transferred to Neodactria in Landry (1995).
Neodactria glenni was described in Landry and Metzler (2002).
Neodactria daemonis and Neodactria oktibbeha were described in Landry and Brown (2005).
Neodactria cochisensis was described in Landry and Albu (2012).
Pseudopediasia was synonymized with Pediasia in Shaffer and Robinson (1987).
Oseriates was synonymized with Pediasia in Landry (1995).
Pseudopediasia mikkolai was synonymized with Pediasia aridella caradjaellus in Shaffer and Robinson (1987).
La cerveza was described in Landry (1995).
Parapediasia hulstellus was transferred from Crambus in Landry (1995).
Parapediasia ligonellus was first reported in the United States from Florida by Landry (1995). Specimens were collected by Jerry Powell from Key Largo, Monroe Co. on 2 Jun 1986.
Parapediasia torquatella was described in Landry (1995).
Almita was described as new genus, and Almita portalia and Almita texana as new species in Landry (1995).
Amphibolia was synonymized with Chrysoteuchia and recognized as a homonym of Macquart 1843 in Bleszynski (1965).
Veronese was synonymized with Chrysoteuchia in Bleszynski (1965).
Crambus pseudorostellus was synonymized with Crambus perlella in Leraut (2012).
Crambus monochromella was recognized as a subspecies in Karsholt (1996).
This species was listed as Incertae sedis by Landry (1995).
All Scirpophaga in the United States were transferred to Carectocultus in Becker and Solis (1990).
Carectocultus repugnatalis was synonymized with Carectocultus perstrialis in Solis and Becker [2003].
All Patissa in the United States were transferred to Leptosteges in Munroe (1995a).
Donacaula was revised by Martinez (2010) in an unpublished dissertation, therefore the new scientific names are not available until they are published.
Lathrotelinae was elevated to subfamily to include the genus Sufetula, closely related to the Acentropinae by Minet (2015).
Perforadix was synonymized with Sufetula in Solis and Shaffer (1999).
Sufetula carbonalis was described in Hayden (2013).
Although Solis (1999) proposed precedence of Nymphulinae over Acentropinae, the ICZN (2003) committee voted to maintain Acentropinae as the valid name.
Oligostigmoides cryptalis was the original spelling; Oligostigmoides cryptale was an unjustified emendation (Hampson 1897).
Synclita was synonymized with Elophila in Speidel (2005).
Munroessa was synonymized with Elophila in Yoshiyasu (1985).
Nymphula ekthlipsis was transferred to Elophila by Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015).
Elophila (Munroessa) serralinealis was no longer recognized as a subspecies in Munroe (1995a).
Hydreuretis and Cosmophylla were synonymized with Parapoynx in Shaffer et al. (1996).
Microdracon was synonymized with Parapoynx in Munroe (1992).
Parapoynx itealis was no longer recognized as a subspecies in Munroe (1995a).
Paraponyx dicentra was synonymized with Paraponyx diminutalis in Shaffer et al. (1996).
Nymphula uxorialis was synonymized with Parapoynx diminutalis in Speidel and Mey (1999).
Chrysendeton nigrescens was described in Heppner (1991).
Argyractis drumalis was indicated as a new combination by Habeck and Solis (1994).
Petrophila heppneri was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1983a).

Acentria was transferred to the Acentropinae (=Nymphulinae) from the Schoenobiinae in Speidel (1984); see also Passoa (1988). Many Old World synonyms were not listed in Munroe (1983), but are included here.
Artopsis was synonymized with Parachma in Barnes and McDunnough (1917).
Artopsis borregalis was synonymized with Parachma ochracealis by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Basacallis was described as new genus for Parachma tarachodes in Cashatt (1984).
Polloccia was synonymized with Acallis in Cashatt (1969).
Acallis centralis was synonymized with Acallis gripalis by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Polloccia alticolalis was transferred to Acallis as a new combination by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (1995).
Acallis mitchelli was transferred to Zaboba in Solis et al. (1995).
Balidarcha was synonymized with Anemosella in Cashatt (1969).
Anemosella polingalis was synonymized with Anemosella basalis by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Balidarcha cuis was synonymized with Anemosella viridalis in Munroe (1983).
Epitamyra albomaculalis was first reported in the United States from Florida by James Hayden in Dixon and Anderson (2014b).
Paragalasa was decribed as new genus with Paragalasa exospinalis as a new species by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Negalasa rubralis was recognized as a species in Solis et al. (1995).
Tetraschistis leucogramma was transferred to Penthesilea and recognized as a junior synonym of Penthesilea difficilis in Solis et al. (1995).
Penthesilea sacculalis baboquivariensis was described as a new subspecies by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Ballonicha and Teucronoma were synonymized with Salobrena in Solis et al. (1995).
Salobrena rubiginea was synonymized with Salobrena recurvata in Solis et al. (1995).
Epitamyra birectalis was transferred to Salobrena and synonymized with Salobrena vacuana in Solis et al. (1995).
Clydonopteron was reinstated as a separate genus from Salobrena in Cashatt (1969).
Clydonopteron tecomae was synonymized with Clydonopteron sacculana in Miller and Becker (1989).
Xantippides was synonymized with Arta in Cashatt (1969).
Xantippides descansalis was synonymized with Arta epicoenalis in Munroe (1983).
Xantippe beatifica was synonymized with Arta epicoenalis by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Arta brevivalvalis was described by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Xantippe uranides was synonymized with Heliades mulleolella by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Heliades lindae was described by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Heliades huachucalis was elevated to species status by Cashatt 2013 in Solis et al. (2013).
Arenipses was synonymized with Aphomia in Kuchlein (1978).
Paralipsa decorella was transferred to Aphomia and synonymized with Aphomia terrenella in Solis and Metz (2008).
Aphomia fulminalis was omitted from the Munroe (1983) list. It was included by Solis and Metz (2008).
Paralipsa and Corcyra were synonymized with Aphomia in Leraut (2014).
Athaliptis was synonymized with Epimorius in Solis [2003].
Epimorius testaceellus was first reported in the United States in Ferguson (1991).
Stenopaschia trichopteris was first reported in the United States from Texas, Cameron Co., Sabal Palm Sanctuary by Knudson (1996).

All species formerly in Macrotheca were placed in Cacotherapia because the former name was preoccupied. Munroe (1995b) made all new species combinations except Cacotherapia angulalis and Cacotherapia bilinealis.
Conobathra and Trachycera were synonymized with Acrobasis in Leraut (2005b).
Hylopylora and Rhodophaeopsis were synonymized with Numonia, which is a synonym of Acrobasis in Roesler (1985, 1987).
Cyphita was synonymized with Conobathra, which is a synonym of Acrobasis in Roesler (1985).
Acrobasis grossbecki was synonymized with Acrobasis indigenella in Neunzig (1986).
Rhodophaea kofa, Rhodophaea fria and Rhodophaea neva were all synonymized with Acrobasis comptella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis feltella was synonymized with Acrobasis palliolella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis kylesi, Almita texana, Acrobasis juglanivorella, and Acrobasis caulivorella were described in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis tumidulella was recognized as a species with Acrobasis kearfottella as a synonym in Leraut (2005b).
Acrobasis peplifera was synonymized with Acrobasis exsulella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis malipennella and Acrobasis secundella were synonymized with Acrobasis normella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis myricella was synonymized with Acrobasis cirroferella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis comacornella was synonymized with Acrobasis caryivorella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis hebescella was synonymized with Acrobasis betulella in Neunzig (1986).
Acrobasis dyarella was synonymized with Acrobasis rubrifasciella in Neunzig (1986).

Rhodophaea was synonymized with Pempelia in Leraut (1997). This genus does not apply to Rhodophaea caliginella and Rhodophaea suavella and Neunzig (1986) transferred them to Trachycera, which was subsequently synonymized with Acrobasis in Leraut (2005b).
Rhodophaea cruza, Rhodophaea durata, and Rhodophaea yuba were all synonymized with Trachycera caliginella in Neunzig (1986). These were then transferred to Acrobasis in Leraut (2005b).
Anypsipyla univitella was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1988).
Crocidomera imitata was described in Neunzig (1990). This entity was formerly included in the check list as turbidella Zell., 1848, but was recognized as a new species in Neunzig (1990).
Neunzig (1990: 34) designated as lectotype the type specimen labeled â€œDioryctria minutulella (sic) Hulstâ€ that Hulst described as minutularia in 1887 and later misspelled in 1890.
Myelois coniella (and thus Rampylla nefas) was synonymized with Myelopsis minutularia in Neunzig (1990).
Myelopsoides was described for the new species Myelopsoides venustus in Neunzig (1998).
Ectomyelois was synonymized with Apomyelois in Leraut (2002).
Fundella agapella was synonymized with Fundella argentina in Landry and Neunzig (1998).
Fundella ignobilis was first reported in the United States from Texas by Knudson (1983).
Scorylus cubensis was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1987).
Anegcephalesis was synonymized with Zamagiria in Neunzig (2003).
Philocrotona was described in Neunzig (2003) with Zamagiria kendalli as the type species.
Pima occidentalis was elevated to species status in Neunzig (2003).
Pima subcostella was no longer recognized as a subspecies in Neunzig (2003).
Pima vividella was synonymized with Pima fulvirugella in Neunzig (2003).
Pima fergusoni was described in Neunzig (2003).
Pimodes caliginosus was described in Neunzig (2003).
Epischnia ruderella was synonymized with Interjectio denticulella in Neunzig (2003).
Ambesa mirabella was elevated to species status in Neunzig (2003).
Ambesa dentifera was described in Neunzig (2003).
Catastia subactualis was described in Neunzig (2003).
Salebriaria ademptanella and Salebriaria robustella were elevated to species status in Neunzig (1988).

Salebriaria borealis, Salebriaria chisosensis, Salebriaria fasciata, Salebriaria rufimaculatella, Salebriaria bella, Salebriaria grandidentalis, Salebriaria equivoca, Salebriaria integra, Salebriaria maximella, Salebriaria simpliciella, Salebriaria carolynae, and Salebriaria squamopalpiella were described in Neunzig (1988).
Salebriaria roseopunctella, Salebriaria kanawha, Salebriaria floridana, and Salebriaria pallidella were described in Neunzig (2003).
Psorosina fergusonella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1983b).
Psorosina fergusonella was transferred to Salebriaria in Neunzig (2003).
Salebriaria atratella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1985b).
Salebriaria atratella, Salebriaria fructetella and Salebriaria occidentalis were transferred to Quasisalebria in Neunzig (2003).
Salebriaria occidentalis was described in Neunzig (1988).
Ortholepis baloghi was described in Neunzig (2003).
Meroptera anaimella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1985c).
Meroptera nevadensis was described in Neunzig (2003).
All species of Nephopterix of the United States were transferred to Sciota in Neunzig (2003), following the European placement of Phycita rhenella in Sciota (Palm 1986; Speidel 1996; Leraut 1997).
Sciota fraudifera was omitted from the Munroe (1983) check list. Neunzig (2003) included this species.
Sciota fraudifera, Sciota floridensis, Sciota levigatella and Sciota yuconella were elevated to species status in Neunzig (2003).
The original spelling of this species by Hulst 1886 was tarmitalis; termitalis was incorrectly used in Munroe (1983) and Neunzig (2003).
Sciota californiana and Sciota quasisubfuscella were described in Neunzig (2003).
Telethusia rhypodella was synonymized with Telethusia ovalis in Neunzig (2003).
Stylopalpia luniferella was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1988) as Stylopalpia lungerella.
The original spelling of this name is luniferella. Both Heinrich (1956) and Munroe (1995a) incorrectly used lunigerella.
Hypochalcia hulstiella was synonymized with Hypochalcia ahnella, and all Palaearctic synonyms are listed in Leraut (2002).
Pyla gaspeensis was synonymized with Pyla aequivoca in Balogh and Wilterding (1998).
Pyla araeneola was described in Balogh and Wilterding (1998).
Many Old World synonyms of Pyla fusca were included in Neunzig (2003).
Pyla westerlandi was described in Wilterding and Balogh (2002).
Pyla longispina and Pyla serrata were described in Neunzig (2003).
Utah was described as a new genus in Ferris (2012a) with the type species sanrafaelensis described as a new species.
Dioryctroides and Ocrisia were synonymized with Dioryctria in Speidel and Asselbergs (2000).
Dioryctria hodgesi, Dioryctria mutuurai, Dioryctria muricativorella, Dioryctria inyoensis and Dioryctria sierra described in Neunzig (2003).
Dioryctria resinosella was described in Mutuura (1982).
Dioryctria delectella and Dioryctria vancouverella were elevated to species status in Neunzig (2003).
Dioryctria yatesi, Dioryctria ebeli and Dioryctria merkeli were described in Mutuura and Munroe (1979).
Dioryctria westerlandi and Dioryctria fordi were described in Donahue and Neunzig [2005].
Dioryctria durangoensis was described in Mutuura and Neunzig (1986).
Dioryctria caesirufella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1983c).
Dioryctria taedivorella was described in Neunzig and Leidy (1989).
Sarata septentrionaria was synonymized with Sarata punctella in Neunzig (2003). It is no longer considered a subspecies.
Sarata alpha is probably the female of Sarata caudellella (Landry 1998); names of unassociated females are not treated in Neunzig (2003).
Lipographis leoninella was synonymized with Lipographis fenestrella in Neunzig (2003).
Lipographis unicolor was described in Ferris (2012b).
Quasisarata was described in Neunzig (2003). Lipographis subosseella is the type species.
Quasisarata subosseella was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1987) in the genus Lipographis.
Pseudadelphia was described in Neunzig (2003).
Ufa roseitinctella was synonymized with Ufa lithosella in Neunzig (2003).
Acroncosa minima was described in Neunzig (2003).
Acroncosa castrella was elevated to species status in Neunzig (2003).
Passadenoides was described for the new species Passadenoides donahuei and Passadenoides pullus in Neunzig (2003).
Passadenoides montanus was described in Ferris (2004).

Chorrera extrincica was first reported in the United States from Texas by Knudson (1983). Neunzig (2003) stated that this species â€œhas been found on two of the Florida Keys (Long Key and Grassy Key, Monroe Co.).
Eumysia pallidipennella was omitted from the Munroe (1983) list, but was listed by Shaffer (1995).
Arcola malloi was first reported from the United States in Brown and Spencer (1973). It was introduced to control alligatorweed (Coulson 1977) and was omitted from the Munroe (1983) list.
Ocala and Divitiaca were synonymized with Macrorrhinia in Neunzig (2003).
Divitiaca simulella was synonymized with Macrorrhinia ochrella in Neunzig (2003).
Shaffer (1991) transferred Rhinaphe endonephele and Rhinaphe ignetincta to Divitiaca (=Macrorrhinia).
Macrorrhinia endonephele was established as an older name for Macrorrhinia ignetincta and Macrorrhinia signifera, both new synonyms, in Neunzig (2003).
Maricopa was recognized as the valid genus name because Valdivia is preoccupied (Shaffer 1995).
Protasia mirabilicornella, described in Valdivia from California, was omitted from Munroe (1983), but listed in Shaffer (1995). It was also reported in Texas by Bordelon and Knudson (2000).
Staudingeria was synonymized with Ancylosis in Leraut (2008).
Pseudocabotia was described for the new species Pseudocabotia balconiensis in Blanchard and Knudson (1985c).
Pseudocabotia was synonymized with Ancylosis in Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Ancylosis bonhoti was first reported in the United States from Florida by Hayden and Dickel (2014).
Palatka powelli was described in Neunzig and Solis (1996).
Anderida peorinella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1985b).
Cassiana malacella was first reported in the United States from the Florida in Neunzig (1997).
Mescinia berosa was reported in United States from Florida in Neunzig (1997).
Mescinia parvula was reported in the United States from Florida in Neunzig (1997).
Mescinia neoparvula was synonymized with Mescinia parvula in Neunzig (1997).
Mescinia texanica was described in Neunzig (1997).

Phestinia costella was discovered in the United States when it was submitted for identification (Solis 2011) for R. Diaz (Diaz et al. 2015). See also Solis et al. (2008) for information about the identity of this species.
Comotia torsicornis was reported for the first time in the United States from Florida by Heppner and Dickel (2008).

Homoeosoma phaeoboreas, Homoeosoma asylonnastes, Homoeosoma oxycercus, Homoeosoma ammonastes, Homoeosoma pedionnastes, Homoeosoma eremophasma, and Homoeosoma ardaloniphas were described in Goodson and Neunzig (1993).
Homoeosoma breviplicitum and Homoeosoma imitator were synonymized with Homoeosoma striatellum in Goodson and Neunzig (1993).
Homoeosoma parvalbum was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1985c).
Homoeosoma emendator was elevated to species status in Goodson and Neunzig (1993).
Homoeosoma nanophasma was described in Neunzig (2003).
Phycitodes albatella is no longer recognized from North America; it occurs only in the Old World.
Phycitodes mucidella and Phycitodes reliquellum were elevated to species status by Neunzig (1997).
Unadilla floridensis was synonymized with Unadilla maturella in Neunzig (1997).
Unadilla nasutella was synonymized with Unadilla erronella in Neunzig (1997).
Laetilia dilatifasciella and Laetilia hulstii were elevated to species status in Neunzig (1997).
Laetilia cinerosella and Laetilia bellivorella were described in Neunzig (1997).
Dakruma pallida was transferred from Laetilia as a new name for Baphala basimaculatella in Neunzig (1997).
Baphala eremiella was elevated to species status in Neunzig (1997).
Baphala phaeolella was described in Neunzig (1997).
Zophodia multistriatella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1981).
Olycella was synonymized with Melitara in Neunzig (1997).
Melitara texana was described in Neunzig (1997).
Melitara doddalis was elevated to species status in Neunzig (1997).
Melitara apicigrammella was described in Blanchard and Knudson (1985c).
Zophodia holochlora was synonymized with Alberada bidentella in Neunzig (1997).
Alberada californiensis, Alberada franclemonti, and Alberada candida were described in Neunzig (1997).
Cactoblastis cactorum was first reported in the United States from Florida in Habeck and Bennett (1990).
Rumatha jacumba was described in Neunzig (1997).
Zophodia longipennella was synonymized with Yosemitia graciella in Neunzig (1997).
Ozamia clarefacta was elevated to species status in Neunzig (1997).
Ozamia lucidalis was first reported in the United States from Florida in Habeck and Bennett (1990).
Echinocereta was described in Neunzig (1997).
Selga californica was described in Neunzig (1990).
Pseudocabima arizonensis was omitted from Munroe (1983), but included by Neunzig (1990).
Euzophera aglaeella was elevated to species status in Neunzig (1990).
Euzophera habrella and Euzophera vinnulella were described in Neunzig (1990).
Ephestiodes monticolus and Ephestiodes griseus were described in Neunzig (1990).
Australephestiodes was described in Neunzig (1990).
Australephestiodes stictella was first reported in the United States from Florida in Neunzig (1990).
Moodnodes was described in Neunzig (1990).
Moodnodes plorella was first reported in the United States from Florida in Neunzig (1990).
Moodna pallidostrinella was described in Neunzig (1990).
Manhatta was synonymized with Vitula in Roesler (1973); also see Neunzig (1990).
Vitula serratilineella was determined to be an older name for Vitula bombylicolella by Sattler (1989).
Vitula serratilineella was elevated to species status in Neunzig (1990).
Vitula aegerella, Vitula insula, and Vitula coconinoana were described in Neunzig (1990).
Volatica gallivorella was described in Neunzig (1990).
Caudellia albovittella was synonymized with Caudellia apyrella in Neunzig (1990).
Caudellia floridensis was described in Neunzig (1990).
Sosipatra proximanthophila and Sosipatra knudsoni were described in Neunzig (1990).
Heinrichiessa was described for the new species Heinrichiessa sanpetella in Neunzig (1990).
Ribua droozi was described in Neunzig (1990).

Ribua innoxia is here reported for the first time in the United States from South Carolina by BGS. A male specimen deposited in the BGS personal collection was collected from Francis Marion NF, Berkeley Co., 7 Sep 2002. A somewhat rubbed male with limited reddish scales, but vinculum distinctly twice as long as wide (see Neunzig 1990 for comparison with Ribua droozi).
Bethulia championella was first reported in the United States Neunzig and Solis (2006).
Anagasta was synonymized with Ephestia in Neunzig (1990).
Homoeosoma ischnomorpha was synonymized with Ephestia kuehniella in Neunzig (1990).
Ephestia columbiella was described in Neunzig (1990).

Tinea aquella is a junior subjective synonym and is an undisputed available name and an unused senior synonym as per Article 23 in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (K. Sattler pers. comm.; see also Sattler and Tremewan 1984 on Denis & SchiffermÃ¼ller names).
Ephestia pterogrisella was synonymized with Ephestia elutella in Neunzig (1990).
Uncitruncata was described for the new species Uncitruncata leuschneri in Neunzig (2000).
Eurythmia furnella was misspelled as fumella in Heinrich (1956) and Munroe (1983).
Eurythmia spaldingella and Eurythmia yavapaella were elevated to species status in Neunzig (1990).
Bema neuricella was first reported in the United States from Florida by Dickel (1987).
Peoria padreella was described in Blanchard (1980).
Peoria insularis was described in Shaffer (2003).
Atascosa heitzmani was described in Shaffer (1980).
Epipaschia zelleri was transferred to Macalla in Solis (1992).
Epipaschia albomedialis was transferred to Cacozelia as a synonym of Cacozelia pemphusalis in Solis (1993).
Jocara interruptella and Jocara elegans were transferred to Cacozelia in Solis (1993).
Tioga neotropica was synonymized with Cacozelia elegans in Solis (1993).
Cacozelia alboplagialis was transferred to Milgithea in Solis (1993).
Milgithea trilinearis was reported as reared in the United States from Florida in Solis (1993).
Toripalpus was resurrected as a genus for Jocara breviornatalis and Jocara trabalis in Solis (1993).
Yuma was omitted from Solis (1993, 1995).
The synonymy of Toripalpus adulatalis was omitted from Solis (1993, 1995).
Deuterollyta was resurrected as a genus to include Jocara incrustalis as a synonym of Deuterollyta majuscula in Solis (1993).
Jocara perseella was synonymized with Deuterollyta majuscula in Solis (1993).
Oneida diploa and Oneida pallidalis were synonymized with Oneida luniferella in Solis (1991).
Oneida grisiella was described in Solis (1991).
Tetralopha and all its synonyms were synonymized with Pococera in Solis (1993).
Salebria nigricans is here transferred to Pococera as a new synonym of Pococera fuscolotella based on MAS examination of type specimen and genitalia slide.
Pococera tertiella was synonymized with Pococera gelidalis in Solis (1993).

Tallula beroella is here reported for the first time from Arizona by MAS. Specimens deposited in the NMNH with the following data: Madera Canyon, Santa Rita Mtns., Santa Cruz Co., J. G. Franclemont, various specimens collected in June and July at elevations around 5000â€™; also one specimen with the same data collected by D. Davis.

Phidotricha was resurrected as a genus to include Phidotricha erigens with Auradisa dryospila as a synonym in Solis (1993). This species was historically misidentified in the literature under the name Pococera atramentalis Lederer, 1863.

Macalla glastianalis was listed as Incertae sedis in Solis (1993). It requires a new genus, inclusion of several Neotropical species, and description of new species. It was first collected by A. Blanchard in Texas in the early 1970â€™s (MAS unpub.).
Several new synonyms for Pyralis farinalis and Pyralis manihotalis were assigned in Shaffer and Solis (1995) and Nuss et al. (2003â€“2015).
Euclita was synonymized with Aglossa in Fletcher and Nye (1984).
Oryctocera, Crocalia, Agriope and were synonymized with Aglossa in Leraut (2003b).
Pyralis costiferalis, Pyralis disciferalis, Pyralis electalis, and Pyralis cacamica were transferred to Aglossa in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Several new synonyms for Aglossa pinguinalis and Aglossa caprealis were assigned in Shaffer and Solis (1995) and Nuss et al. (2003-2015).
Dolichomia, Herculia, Cisse, Buzala, Ocrasa, Bejuda, Pseudasopia, and Orthopygia were synonymized with Hypsopygia in Leraut (2006a).
Bleone was synonymized with Hypsopygia in Leraut (2003a).
Parasopia was synonymized with Hypsopygia in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Pyralis intermedialis, Asopia binodulalis, Pyralis nostralis, and Pyralis olinalis were transferred to Hypsopygia in Leraut (2006a).
Pyralis nostralis was placed in Ocrasa (=Hypsopygia) in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Parasopia dissimilalis, Ocrasa sordidalis, Herculia psammioxantha, and Herculia venezuelensis were synonymized with Dolichomia (=Hypsopygia) nostralis in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Herculia infimbrialis was synonymized with Dolichomia (=Hypsopygia) olinalis in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Uscodys was synonymized with Arispe in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Uscodys atalis was synonymized with Arispe cestalis in Shaffer and Solis (1995).
Neodavisia melusina was described in Ferguson et al. (1984).
Austromusotima camptozonale was released but not established in Florida (Boughton and Pemberton 2012).

Blepharocerus rosellus and Blepharocerus ignitalis were evidently inserted into the MONA list inadvertently by Munroe (1983). They had not been listed in any previous check lists, and we have found no documented records. Both species are described from Chile.
Solis and Metz (2008) indicated that Aphomia fuscolimbella is likely not of North American origin.
Although covered in Neunzig (1986), he mentions that Cryptoblabes gnidiella is still not recorded from North America, but it is known from Bermuda, Central and South America, and Hawaii.
Although included in Munroe (1983), there is no evidence to indicate that Apomyelois decolor occurs in the United States, and Neunzig (1990) did not include this species.
Myelois grossipunctella was reported from the United States but not established and not reported again (Shaffer et al. 1996).
Myelois grossipunctella was found to be a senior synonym of Creobota coccophthora by Shaffer et al. (1996) transferring grossipunctella to Creobota.
Homoeosoma pseudonimbella was found to be a synonym of Phycitodes albatella by Leraut (2002).
Cactobrosis longipennella was removed from United States faunal list in Neunzig (1997).
Vitula lugubrella was found to be a synonym of Vitula biviella, a European species. The California description is believed to be in error according to Neunzig (1990).

Coenodomus hockingi was included in Munroe (1983) based on the description of Dyaria singularis from Maine. This locality is now believed to be either in error, or a one time introduction that was not established, and this species is removed from the check list (Solis 1992).
Pococera atramentalis Lederer, 1863 was included in Munroe (1983) as a result of misidentifications in the literature (see Note #396).
Hemimatia atramentalis was transferred to Tallula in Solis (1993). Tallula atramentalis (Lederer, 1863)(Hemimatia), described from Venezuela, does not occur in the U.S.
